title: 103_s2476
content: The "Individual Retirement Account Equity and Enhancement Act of 1994" allows homemakers to be eligible for a full IRA deduction. Spousal IRA contribution limit based on combined spousal compensation. The limit is the lesser of $2,000 or the total compensation of both spouses minus any deduction claimed by the spouse. Applies to certain married individuals. The amendments made by this section apply to married individuals filing joint returns with compensation less than their spouse's, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 1994. Amendments include changes to contribution limits and definitions in specific sections. Distributions from certain plans can be used penalty-free for first homes, higher education, qualified long-term care expenses, or by the long-term unemployed. Distributions from certain plans can be penalty-free for first home purchases, educational expenses, or long-term care costs. Qualified first-time homebuyer distributions allow individuals to use payments or distributions for qualified acquisition costs towards a first-time homebuyer's principal residence within 60 days of receipt. Qualified acquisition costs include acquiring, constructing, or reconstructing a residence. Qualified first-time homebuyer distributions allow individuals to use payments for qualified acquisition costs towards a first-time homebuyer's principal residence. A first-time homebuyer is defined as an individual who had no ownership interest in a principal residence in the 3-year period before acquisition. The distribution from an individual retirement plan must meet certain requirements for a qualified first-time homebuyer to use payments for acquisition costs towards a principal residence. The terms "principal residence" and "date of acquisition" have specific meanings in this context. If there is a delay in acquiring the residence, a special rule applies. The distribution from an individual retirement plan for a qualified first-time homebuyer can be contributed to an IRA if there is a delay in purchasing the residence. This contribution is subject to specific rules and does not affect other contributions or eligibility criteria for IRA contributions. Qualified higher education expenses include tuition, fees, books, supplies, and equipment necessary for enrollment. The tax code allows for deductions on qualified higher education expenses and qualified long-term care expenses. Qualified higher education expenses cover tuition, fees, books, supplies, and equipment necessary for enrollment at an eligible educational institution. Qualified long-term care expenses include amounts paid for services and insurance covering such services. The term 'qualified long-term care services' refers to necessary diagnostic, preventive, therapeutic, rehabilitative, and maintenance services provided to functionally impaired individuals as part of a continuing care plan. The term 'functionally impaired individual' refers to someone certified by a licensed health care practitioner as unable to perform at least 3 activities of daily living without substantial assistance. For home health care services, a special rule applies when services are provided in the individual's home, with a substitution of '2' for '3'. Nursing homes or similar facilities are not considered homes. Activities of daily living include eating, transferring, toileting, dressing, and bathing. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of a licensed health care practitioner for the purpose of bathing services. It includes physicians, registered nurses, qualified community care case managers, and individuals meeting specific requirements set by the Secretary. The curr_chunk outlines the qualifications for individuals providing case management services, including experience in care planning and assessing functional impairments. They must not be a relative of the individual receiving services and meet requirements set by the Secretary. The term 'relative' is defined as per section 152(a). The curr_chunk discusses penalty-free distributions for unemployed individuals from individual retirement plans under certain conditions. It includes requirements related to receiving unemployment compensation for 12 consecutive weeks and the timing of distributions. Additionally, there are conforming amendments to section 401(k)(2)(B)(i) outlined. The curr_chunk discusses penalty-free distributions for qualified first-time homebuyer, higher education, and long-term care expenses from individual retirement plans. Amendments are made to section 403(b)(11) to allow for these distributions. The amendments made by this section allow penalty-free distributions for qualified first-time homebuyer, higher education, and long-term care expenses from individual retirement plans. Effective date applies to payments and distributions after the enactment of this Act.
